svcprocinfo.para: The ECM is used to control the Kysor engine cooling fan. Other fan control components include:

item.para: A Normally Closed (N.C.) Air Conditioning (AC) High Pressure Switch (236).
A sealed N.O. Fan Control relay (315).

svcprocinfo.para: The ECM Cooling Fan relay is controlled by the Coolant Temperature Sensor, Coolant Temperature Sensor combined with the Retarder Solenoids and the AC High Pressure switch.

svcsubproc.title: Kysor Fan/Clutch Assembly
svcsubproc.para: The fan clutch is dis-engaged by air pressure supplied by the Fan Solenoid. The fan clutch is spring loaded ON and air pressure is required to overcome the spring and dis-engage the fan clutch.

svcsubproc.title: Kysor Normally Closed (N.C.) Fan Solenoid (239)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.04
, for this discussion.

The N.C. fan solenoid (239) does not supply air pressure to dis-engage the fan clutch when the solenoid is not energized. Energizing the solenoid turns ON the air pressure to the fan clutch, causing the Fan clutch to dis-engage (see Figure 2.07).

The solenoid receives Ignition voltage (key on) on circuit 23 from 10A fuse F1-D. The solenoid ground circuit, 23B, is connected to the normally open contact of the Engine Fan Relay (315). The Engine Fan relay opens and closes, causing the Fan Solenoid to turn on and off (Figure 2.08).

svcsubproc.title: Fan Control Relay (315)
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to
CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS, Figure 6.04
, for this discussion.

The Fan Control relay control coil is energized by a 12V signal on circuit 23A from ECM connector (558) terminal 28. The relay control coil ground circuit 23-GB and circuit 23-GA (attached to the common relay contact 30) are grounded through the engine harness to the cylinder head ground.

When the ECM energizes the Fan Control relay, the N.O. contacts close, completing the circuit to ground for circuit 23B, causing the fan solenoid to energize. This dis-engages the fan clutch (Figure 2.08).

The ECM uses inputs from the Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor, Retarder Solenoid and the AC High Pressure switch (236) to determine when the fan should be ON. The Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor and Retarder Solenoid are installed by Caterpillar and International installs the AC pressure switch. To turn the fan ON, the ECM applies 0V to the Fan Control Relay. To turn the fan OFF, the ECM
applies 12V to the Fan Control relay.
The ECM turns the fan ON under the following conditions:
If the engine speed is LESS than 2250 RPM or the engine is not running and any of the following conditions exist:
Coolant Temperature Sensor is greater than 205°F (96°C) OR
There is an active diagnostic code for the Coolant Temperature Sensor OR
The Retarder Solenoids Active in the High mode for more than 10 seconds with Coolant Temperature Sensor greater than 176°F (80°C) OR
AC High Pressure Switch Open OR
There is an active diagnostic code for an Open AC High Pressure Switch circuit.
The ECM turns the fan OFF under the following conditions:
Engine speed is greater than 2300 RPM or all of the following conditions exist:
Coolant Temperature sensor less than 198°F (92°C) and
No Active Coolant Temperature sensor diagnostic code and
Retarder Solenoids Active in High mode with Coolant Temperature sensor less than 167°F (75°C) and
AC High Pressure switch is closed and the ECM is not counting (or AC Fan ON time is programmed to zero seconds) and
The engine has been running at least two seconds.

note.para: Once the ECM has turned the fan ON, the fan will remain ON for a minimum of 180 seconds to avoid unnecessary fan clutch cycling (except at engine startup- it will run for only two seconds after the engine starts). The 180 second time interval is a programmable feature.
